Award.AwardTitle: Implementation of Student- Centered Pedagogy, Its Impact on Learning, Persistence, and the Teaching Culture

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project will significantly improve the learning environment for thousands of life science majors by converting introductory courses in biology and math to student-centered modes of instruction. Instructor teams will be trained to use interactive video technology to implement active learning pedagogies in core biology courses. The project team also will design a new math curriculum that incorporates biology-relevant content and computational applications, supplemental instruction opportunities for underrepresented racial minority students, and student-centered teaching methods demonstrated to positively impact students most at risk for dropping out of science. Expected outcomes include more students motivated and prepared to explore diverse science careers, fewer students under-performing in their introductory coursework, and a more diverse undergraduate pool completing science and math degrees. Project activities also will produce research faculty who are more engaged in assessing student learning as well as future faculty (teaching fellows) who can serve as advocates of student-centered teaching at other institutions. To augment these activities, a new position will be created within the UCLA Career Center that promotes student interest in career alternatives to medicine and awareness of emerging careers in science. The project evaluation plan will provide new knowledge about the impact of interactive videos on student learning, the effectiveness of student-centered teaching on knowledge retention and persistence in science majors, and the support structures necessary to engage research-focused faculty in curricular reform. All of these activities will incorporate faculty mentoring strategies and incentives aimed at surmounting institutional barriers that tend to inhibit educational reform.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to support the success and persistence of life science STEM majors by implementing evidence-based, student-centered teaching as a cultural norm in gateway courses at a large, public, selective, research-intensive university. There were three parts to this project:

Part 1 focused on the introductory biology curriculum and involved conversion of lecture-based courses to a highly-structured, flipped (HSF) format. Over 8,000 undergraduates annually enroll in these courses, which prepare students for entry into any one of 12 life science majors. Courses are taught by both research-intensive faculty members and several full-time, dedicated biology instructors. A cadre of teaching specialists, referred to Discipline-Based Education Research, or DBER, postdoctoral fellows, were recruited to pair with research faculty and instructors to form DBER Teams who developed teaching materials, including a repository of interactive videos and active learning resources, and implemented new pedagogy in three new biology courses. Course descriptions can be viewed on the department website: https://www.lscore.ucla.edu.

DBER postdoctoral fellows initiated research studies investigating specific components of the new biology courses, resulting in two peer-reviewed publications. The first was a study on the impact of undergraduate Learning Assistants (LAs), who were introduced to facilitate active learning in the molecular biology course (see Sallami et al. 2017). Positive outcomes prompted expansion of the LA program into many other life science STEM gateway courses. Another research study was undertaken to determine the effects of introducing seductive details (SDs), which are interesting but irrelevant details or anecdotes, into pre-class lecture videos (see Maloy et al. 2019). The HSF classroom model enabled us to determine the impact of SDs on students in an actual course (as opposed to lab environment where SDs were previously studied), with data showing they are memorable and did not harm students' content attainment, interest, or perceived learning.

Part 2 centered around the development of a new contextualized math curriculum comprised of two math courses that incorporate biology-relevant content and computational applications (see textbook by Garfinkel et al. 2017). A research study was conducted to examine the performance outcomes of students in contextualized math compared to students in traditional calculus. A manuscript describing the results was submitted to CBE-Life Sciences Education for publication consideration (see Sanders O'Leary et al.). Our findings demonstrate that the new contextualized math courses provide students with the quantitative training necessary for success in future courses in chemistry and physics and enhance student interest in mathematical approaches to biological questions. As a result of this study, nearly all life science majors at UCLA now complete the new math curriculum instead of traditional calculus.

Part 3 explored the impact of creating an undergraduate STEM career development course on student interest in career alternatives to medicine, awareness of emerging careers in STEM, and motivation to complete a STEM degree in life sciences. The course now engages an average of 250 students for each of two academic terms per year with a version exclusively offered to around 60 transfer students each fall term. Video testimonials (https://ceils.ucla.edu/ls110/) with course alumni showcase the benefits of the course, and our assessment based on pre/post surveys and reflective writing assignments has been submitted for publication consideration to Frontiers in Education (see Liu et al.).

Overall, this project had a significant impact on the teaching culture. Rigorous student assessment played an indispensable role driving changes in policy and practice across the sciences and also motivated a shift in departmental attitudes about teaching in STEM courses. Recent analysis of persistence trends for underrepresented students in life sciences shows a steady increase in the 4th year retention rate between 2012 and 2018 that is not evident in other science areas on campus. It is clear that we realized a combined benefit of these curricular interventions in which persistence rates improved, particularly among those students most vulnerable to STEM exclusion.
